title: Will RWA Tokenization Be the Next ETF? - Eric Piscini, CEO Hashgraph

cleanText:
Hello and welcome back to Cointelegraph's live stream right here from Paris at Proof of Talk.
We are talking to a number of bigname speakers that have taken the stage here at this fantastic event.
If you are watching the live stream on X or YouTube, please go ahead and drop your questions in the channel if you want to pose some questions to our guests throughout the day.
We will continue to be live a few more times this afternoon.
So keep it locked on Cointelegraph socials as we go.
I'm joined now by CEO of Hashgraph, Eric Piscini.
Um we actually just sat on a panel this morning talking about AI and blockchain.
Um but let's just set the scene for the viewers out there that aren't too familiar with Hedera and Hashgraph.
Uh what you guys do, what your real use case is and and the majority of your your users around the world.
Yeah, good.
Thank you for having me.
Um it's been fun here right in Paris.
I was born here so I always love coming back here.
Um so Hedera is a project that that started in 2018.
Uh Dr. Leemon Baird and men arand started the project the co-founders and the foundation was we're going to build a very efficient higherforming layer one that is going to be able to activate any kind of use cases with very specific characteristics.
One, the transaction fees are denominated in dollars, not in crypto, which means that if you're a business, you can build an application and know exactly how much you're going to pay in the future.
Very important.
Second is the technology itself, which is technically if you're in technology is not a blockchain.
It's a DAG with a gossip mechanism.
You can look it up.
There's a lot of interesting things that Dr. Man invented and they are part of this very very unique and the third piece is Hedera as a council which actually is meeting today in DC so I'm missing the cancel meeting as we speak but the cancel is um 30 plus organizations running the network on behalf of the ofa right soa is a public ledger but permissioned because only those 30 organizations can run the network and there are Google and IBM and Dell and many many big big firms doing this and I'm the CEO of Hashgraph and Hashgraph is the team behind the Hedera network.
So the founders are with Hashgraph everybody in marketing, communication, product engineering, security blah blah blah blah blah.
Everybody is working for Hashgraph pretty much except for the people giving grants to activate the ecosystems and they are working for the Hedera Foundation.
When it comes to talking about um Hashgraph and Hedera not being a blockchain but a DAG um maybe you can just explain that a little bit more and why that specific use case works in the industry and why it's very uh favorable for enterprises and people that want a sort of more permissioned network than they would get with using Ethereum or something else.
Yeah.
And so it's a little bit of a a layer game, right?
So which layer are you are you looking at?
So if you look at blockchain today uh one of the challenges of a traditional let's call that traditional blockchain is uh performance because you have to wait for the blocks to be created to get finality of your transactions and the second challenge is fair ordering right and with DAG when we are not the only DAG in the market by the way but with DAG you actually avoid that you don't have to think of those issues because you are providing by default fair ordering which is extremely extremely important in capital markets.
Yeah.
Right.
Uh you don't want someone to front run you when you about to trade something, right?
A token or anything.
Uh and then the second piece is it's it's much more uh the performance of the network is much faster.
So for example, we can go to 20,000 transaction per second at the layer one.
Right?
So typically you get that level of performance at layer twos because they cannot achieve that on Ethereum or you know any other layer one.
We are really really efficient.
That's the value of DAG, right?
And then of course that translates into adoption by enterprise, adoption by the retail market because they can benefit from those two things, fair ordering and high performance.
Yeah.
Um I've got a question coming in uh from the live stream and I'm I'm just going to pose it to you from Bisben.
You connected a SpaceX satellite project.
Do you really expect IoT scale adoption from space or is this sci-fi hype?
I think that's quite an interesting question.
Um so it's hard to comment on, you know, rumors, right?
Um so you know the what I can say is that our blockchain would be really well positioned to support the use case which is payments right because we can do that uh very efficiently.
So for example a a consensus transaction uh is a fraction of a cent dollar cent uh so when you do payments and your transaction fees are you know 50 cents that could limit you in what you can do from a payment point of view because we are a fraction of a cent in some in some cases hundreds of a cent right so really really cheap transaction fees then you can actually enable micro payments yes and and um payment streaming right And so of course those platforms that we've been for others can be used by major organizations to deliver their own payment solutions.
When it comes to the the Hedera Council and and all these bigname you know household uh institutions being part of that council, some people in the ecosystem might say that this is never going to be as decentralized as you would want it to be if only a handful of participants can be the network validators as it were.
What are your thoughts on that and and the general approach?
So, I'm I'm going to create a storm on Twitter if I answer the but but that's okay.
Um um we did an analysis, right?
You have the the Nakamoto uh ratio, right?
The decentralization ratio.
Um and we looked at that against Ethereum for example.
And because of the Ethereum pools, right, we were actually on par with Ethereum when it comes to decentralization because we do have really independent organization that are running the nodes.
But I would argue that quality in decentralization of the node is actually more important than the quantity.
Yes.
And let me explain when IBM, Google and Dell are saying we are going to run a node on Hedera, right?
They are not just committing to stake, they are also committing a brand, their brand to support a project and they will never do something dramatic or nefarious against the network because they would damage their brands, right?
So that is an additional layer of um another dimension of analysis when you think about decentralization because it depends on who is actually enabling that decentralization.
I think that's really important in our context.
It's interesting that you say that because I met the the head of web 3 at Amazon earlier today at the the breakfast that we were at and and I look I know this as a fact but I don't think a lot of people do.
You know more than 50% of um you know Ethereum's validator infrastructure is running on AWS servers.
So when when you think about it like that it's like if we're going to be pointing fingers at people for centralization.
Exactly.
So we pay a lot of attention to that too.
So for example, I think we have 20 different cloud and infrastructure locations running nodes.
So we are not centralized from a cloud infrastructure point of view either.
Right.
That's a really important topic.
You're right.
Um I've got another question coming from the from the the live stream and please do keep them keep them coming through.
This is your chance to ask some of the big names the industry the the hard questions that I might not be willing to ask.
Not too hell.
Not too hard.
You can always say no comments.
Um yeah, from Ola XT, RWA tokenization is sparking.
Swell's swell calls brewing.
What's the play behind this trigger?
Let's talk about RWA tokenization.
Um I just spoke to Reeve Collins who was one of the original founders of Tether and I think that's the original RWA tokenization.
You know, tokenizing dollars, that's that's one one flavor.
It's now morphed into something way bigger.
You can do property, you can be tokenized securities, you know, everything and anything.
Um, do you see that as the real future like core use for a lot of these different blockchain protocols that exist today?
Yes, but not the only one, right?
So, I think I think tokenization is was part of the foundation of blockchain, right?
I've been in blockchain for 12 years.
Yeah, we were talking about tokenization maybe with different names, but we are talking about tokenizing assets.
Whether it's a physical asset, a digital asset, an identity, a right, a legal right, we've been tokenizing from the beginning.
So tokenization is just getting more traction today because now we finally are able to deliver those solutions around tokenization at scale.
I think that's so it's not a new thing.
Yeah.
But it's getting more traction today because we can actually deliver at scale.
What's exciting to me is um you you you create an environment with tokenization where you democratize access to a lot of things that people don't have access to and yes technology is one piece of the solution the regulatory environment has to change as well right so if you're in the US and you want to invest into a real estate project typically you have to have a lot of money and you have to be an accredited investor with tokenization You don't have to have a lot of money anymore because you can invest a $100 in but you still have to be an accredited investor.
Yes.
Right.
So there is the technology piece is fixed now.
It's done.
Now we have to fix the regulatory environment.
But if you scale out and you say at the global level now you can you have people in other jurisdictions who can invest into assets in the US and vice versa at a very low cost with a secondary market.
And that really change the nature of markets.
Yeah.
Uh and we're going to see that around real estate.
We have a project on real estate, many projects, but one that's very very uh well known by our community called Rats One.
Okay.
And we are tokenizing real estate and enabling people to invest and resell their participation into real estate projects on on Hedera.
Okay.
So, that's a key use case, right?
I mean, and and a very real one that exists.
It's very real.
It's on it's live.
You can invest into those things right now.
Um if you're in the US you have limitations as I said earlier uh but we tokenized you know money market fund we tokenized uh m mutual funds we tokenize you know identity which is usually not we we don't talk much about identity anymore but that's one way to tokenize as well you tokenize your own identity or you tokenize the identity of your AI agent which is maybe the next topic right AI.
Yeah.
Yeah, definitely.
Um, let's talk a little bit about AI.
I mean, Hashgraph is now integrating some some AI functionality into what you can do.
Um, tell us what that looks like and and what the future sort of integration and use of AI uh for for your organization and your layer one is in the future.
I think and this morning we were talking about it was great by the way.
It was really really good discussion.
Thank you for um moderating and and asking the right questions too.
You're welcome.
Um and and we were talking about three different layers of AI and blockchain, right?
So the first one is decentralized AI.
So we cannot continue to run AI infrastructure and AI models just in centralized entities, right?
Because they own everything.
They own your input, they own your output, they own the models, they own the data.
They're going to get better and better and better.
And um we we don't want to recreate a world where they control everything because we are going to be interacting with AI a lot in the future.
So we need to find a way to decentralize that infrastructure.
So if one of the big AI company tomorrow for some reason stops to operate, we can still benefit from that model because it is a decentralized infrastructure.
Yeah.
So that's number one.
Number two is when those AI activities are taking place, we need a a trust layer for the AI supply chain, right?
So from the sourcing of the data to the running of the model to the learning activities to the output and the output turning into an input all of those events must be reconnected on a ledger on a public ledger or a private ledger depending on the scenario but on a trust layer and the trust layer is a in our context and we connect all of that here.
